title: polynomials - Interlaced binomial expansion
body: For $a_1,a_2,\ldots,a_n < 1$ let $$f(a_1,a_2,\ldots,a_n) = \sum_{k_1,k_2,...,k_n = 1}^\infty \frac{(k_1 + k_2)!}{k_1! k_2!} \frac{(k_2 + k_3)!}{k_2! k_3!}\ldots \frac{(k_{n-1} + k_{n})!}{k_{n-1}! k_{n}!} a_1^{k_1} a_2^{k_2} \ldots a_n^{k_n}$$ Any idea how to attack this problem? At least for $n=3$ ... polynomials binomial-coefficients Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jul 20, 2020 at 12:55 tomate 513 2 2 silver badges 12 12 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 3 4 $\begingroup$ what is the problem? $\endgroup$ Fedor Petrov –  Fedor Petrov 2020-07-20 13:29:15 +00:00 Commented Jul 20, 2020 at 13:29 $\begingroup$ If you are interested in getting simple rational expressions for $f(a_1,\ldots,a_n)$, I would change the lower bound in the sum to 0 first. $\endgroup$ Timothy Budd –  Timothy Budd 2020-07-20 16:37:02 +00:00 Commented Jul 20, 2020 at 16:37 $\begingroup$ Fedor: finding explicit rational expressions. $\endgroup$ tomate –  tomate 2020-07-21 06:42:38 +00:00 Commented Jul 21, 2020 at 6:42 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
